content.title: Carotid Body Tumor (Paraganglioma)
content.definition: A carotid body tumor is a rare, slow-growing paraganglioma arising from chemoreceptor cells at the carotid bifurcation, presenting as a painless neck mass that splays the internal and external carotid arteries (lyre sign).

epidemiology.altitude_association: More common in populations living at high altitude (chronic hypoxia)

pathology.origin: Chief cells of carotid body (neural crest derived)

shamblin_classification.type_i: Small, minimal attachment to vessels, easily resectable
shamblin_classification.type_iii: Completely encases carotid, may require sacrifice/reconstruction

characteristics.location: Anterior to SCM at carotid bifurcation
characteristics.mobility: Mobile side-to-side but not vertically (Fontaine sign)

clinical_presentation.cranial_nerve_deficits: X (hoarseness), XII (tongue deviation), IX if large

imaging.ct_cta: Hypervascular mass at carotid bifurcation, splaying ICA/ECA
imaging.mri_mra: Flow voids ('salt and pepper' appearance on T1/T2)
imaging.angiography: 'Lyre sign' - splaying of ICA and ECA around mass

diagnosis.genetic_testing: SDH mutation screening if familial or bilateral

surgical_resection.indication: Standard of care for most patients
surgical_resection.shamblin_iii: May require carotid resection and reconstruction
surgical_resection.preoperative_embolization: Consider for large tumors to reduce bleeding

treatment.radiation: For unresectable, incomplete resection, malignant, high-risk patients

screening_relatives.indications: Bilateral tumor, family history, young age, multiple paragangliomas
screening_relatives.imaging: MRI neck and abdomen for multiple paragangliomas

learning_objectives: Describe clinical presentation and examination findings
Apply Shamblin classification to surgical planning
Identify imaging findings of carotid body tumor
clinical_pearls: Lyre sign: ICA and ECA splayed around tumor on angiography
Fontaine sign: Mobile side-to-side but not vertically
Biopsy is contraindicated - highly vascular tumor
Consider SDH mutation testing if bilateral, familial, or young patient
